comments.commentBody:
The economic battle royal has a cultural component. This $750K Koch-funded video targets young adults and uses imagery to urge them to "opt out" of Obamacare. If they opt out, it becomes more difficult to cover the costs of the poor.

Some have called it the creepiest 60 second video in the last 8 years. It's an eye witness measure of values that often have been hidden that now lay exposed: [http://wp.me/p1mBVu-2zE].

Harsh to fault the team, if they come down any harder they run the risk of being accused of censorship and risk alienating a much needed fan base.  Blame goes to the idiots who insist on the boorish display.  Agree it's not a bribe; agree that it's unimaginative.

@Bakes, normally, I would concede the point about being harsh on the team, except for one thing: it could be used "for travel." Is the team saying that the least controllable fans that they have are given travel incentives to go to away matches? That would be tragically slapheaded thinking, my friend.

"They told their three official supporters groups that they would receive $500 for every game in which they displayed progress. It was not a cash award; the money would essentially be credit the fans could use toward game paraphernalia and travel. Still, some characterized the offer as a bribe, which the club has rigorously disputed."

It's not a bribe, it's an economic incentive. The worst part is not the vulgarity, it's the utter lack of imagination, both in the chant and in the teams' response to it.

Harsh to fault the team, if they come down any harder they run the risk of being accused of censorship and risk alienating a much needed fan base.  Blame goes to the idiots who insist on the boorish display.  Agree it's not a bribe; agree that it's unimaginative.

@Bakes, normally, I would concede the point about being harsh on the team, except for one thing: it could be used "for travel." Is the team saying that the least controllable fans that they have are given travel incentives to go to away matches? That would be tragically slapheaded thinking, my friend.

"YSA" is certainly not clever, but profane? Barely. I'm dreading the day NBC realizes that Premier League crowds are singing truly unpublishable verses that can be deciphered from TV, and decides to broadcast games without crowd noise. The investment and excitement of the fans is a major part of what makes games fun to watch and take part in. That's not to condone truly offensive (versus merely juvenile) lyrics, but so much of fan culture is the passing down of songs and chants that get appropriated and rewritten and drunkenly belted from the terraces. I don't think MLS or any league wants to muzzle the ticket buyers, or indeed return to the days of unsold tickets.

I once made the mistake of unwittingly buying Red Bull tickets in the Empire Supporters Club/Viking Army rooting section.

What a nightmare.

They made the game as enjoyable as a rumble.

Soccer is a tremendous sport.

That it attracts more orchestrated hooliganism than other sports is a black mark on soccer.

Uncivilized rabble.

ClearWindow, I would recommend this 100x if I could. I really do not understand why American soccer fans cannot develop their own way of being fans instead of pathetically copying Europeans. I often consider going to a Red Bulls game, but I am turned off by the American fan groups who are trying to act like Europeans (note that the same goes for the US MNT). Now, if I were going to a game in Europe, that would be great, since it would be part of the local atmosphere.

It reeks of when rich suburban kids pose as gang members, having no idea what that really is. Turn these wannabees loose in a European stadium, and they won’t know what hit them.

I don't think I have ever agreed with you on anything soccer-related before, but you absolutely hit this one out the park. Your use of the quotes for "Ultras" is spot-on. European Ultras are the most violent, racist, disruptive and obnoxious of all soccer fans, and it's very poor form that this particular Red Bulls "supporter" group would align itself under such a banner. Ultras are associated with Fascism, racism and renascent Nazism... and to adopt such a name reeks of desperation on the part of this selective collection of idiots.

As for the other fans insistent on the profane and unimaginative chanting, they have chosen to imitate the basest of behavior of foreign fans. The YSA chant is reminiscent and redolent of the ridiculously childish "p_ta" chant seemingly so popular in many Central and S. American countries. At risk of being accused of prejudice, I have never heard any such chanting (when the goalkeeper kicks the ball) in my many years of watching European (many different leagues/countries), African, Asian and even Caribbean football (soccer).

Thanks Bakes.
I will though, fight the good Pier 40 fight, desperate though it may be, until something else goes shovel into the ground there. Still fighting New York State Senate Bill S5824, which hasn't been signed yet. Ain't over til it's over...

http://nycmls.com/2013/02/15/soccer-is-still-the-answer-for-pier-40-and-...

So much emerging American soccer culture has become fan groups aspiring lamely to pretend to be "ultras" or other actual criminal or violent enterprises which attend in other countries. It's pathetic. Create your own reality, Americans. With your little crib sheets of what to yell, and when to yell it, you're becoming nothing more than the "make some noise" text on the jumbotron. Trying so hard to prove that you're the first ever Americans to support soccer, falling all over themselves to try and be like South Americans or Europeans or Balkans to do so.

The end result of this is that those of us all over the country who have been fighting difficult battles to try and get our communities and community boards to allow new arenas to be developed, continuously have to deal with the formerly meritless contentions by people who know nothing of soccer, that they are going to have to defend themselves against some ill defined notion of "hooligans". You're giving them all the ammunition they need.

Our own people are shooting us in the feet. They are making it impossible to make any headway in the efforts to expand the league.

Get over yourselves, and show some support for expansion, and a different kind of fan base than the NFL. Faddishly trying to be something you're not and watching it kill the efforts of the rest of us is selfish and tedious.

There are real efforts at stake every day, and they have no idea how much damage they are doing.
Your comment could have been exhibit A of Daniel Patrick Moynihan's catalog of examples demonstrating the trend of defining down deviancy. Well done.
I don't think it's puritanism, just a stand against rampant vulgarity.  Your 3-year old is not one I want to meet, I think.

When are Americans going to get over this bizarre puritanical insanity? Ours is a culture that has no issue with depictions of wholesale slaughter but goes crazy at language and views of the human body?

Curse words are a part of the language and hold no mystery for any child above the age of 3, give it a rest already.
The network and the broadcast implications are what will grow the league.  They are paramount.
Exactly.  There is no moral outrage here - it's ALL about the Benjamins.  Nothing more, nothing less.

Benjamins grow the league.  We need to grow the league.  No problem here.  But no one said anything about no moral outrage.  Ask any parent with a kid at the game.  In my entire life of watching matches in the US, and that includes ASL, MLS, Gold Cup, friendlies, Cup qualifying and now MLS, where there has been one raucous atmosphere after another (Cleveland Force in the playoffs at the Richfield Coliseum anyone?)  this fake, loser wannabe chanting trying to ape the Europeans behavior has NEVER been a problem.  It's faddish behavior by impatient fans trying too hard to create tradition overnight.
I'm not in favor of the chant, but it sounds like the real underlying frustration lies with the networks and broadcast implications, not the fans or players at the actual game.

Some years ago, I had an elderly British couple as my guests, and I took them to the Carrier Dome to see what turned out to be Syracuse upsetting Nebraska.  It was an exciting game, and they enjoyed it, but afterwards they told me that they had been a bit scared to go.  They assumed that, as a "football" game, it might be a somewhat dangerous event to attend.  They said they were "surprised" at how well behaved the fans were.

And actually, there is a device that is sometimes used against public speakers. It uses a real time, slightly delayed audio, feeding it back in a  highly directional beam. It silences individuals and I have no doubt it will silence chanters.
Brilliant!  YSA will become "Buy Coca-Cola!" Another win for America.

Come on, come on. Sample the audio profile of the chant once or twice, invert the waveform of the profile to cancel it, and apply the filter to the audio stream.

I'm simplifying, yes, but this is doable. We can auto-tune the worst vocalists so they sing to true pitch and make milliions. We can't do this ??
More than merely seems, I'm afraid.
Does it seem that our whole society is descending to a level of coarseness that any dignified person would find abhorrent?
Empty seats?? Have you seen a telecast of the Portland Timbers, Seattle Sounders, or Columbus Crew home games?
No, empty seats are due to second rate teams with has-been Euro players trying to attract publicity.  US soccer is B-league at best.

@TJ: There are plenty of empty seats at Red Bull Arena. But the comparison of attendance figures to the NBA and NHL is utterly unfair, due to the lack of comparable nature of the arenas involved. Even the smallest of MLS "soccer specific" stadia has a far greater capacity than almost every indoor arena in the country. Madison Square Garden, the supposed "world's most famous arena," has a capacity of 19500 for basketball and 17500 for hockey. An average crowd in that range is the norm these days at Red Bull Arena, with a capacity of 26,000. If you want to make a fair comparison, try comparing percentage of tickets sold. And you're in Maryland. There are LOTS and LOTS of empty seats when DC United plays at RFK Stadium, aren't there?
Here is the aggregate and average attendance figures for the last MLS season. http://espnfc.com/stats/attendance/_/league/usa.1/major-league-soccer?cc... Please note that near the bottom of the league attendance figures are the dismal teams of DC United and New England Revolution, both averaging under 14K fans per match in stadia capable of holding 50,000+. And the bottom of the league is Chivas USA, which averages 8,237 in THE SAME STADIUM where the LA Galaxy averages 22,283.
This behavior sure doesn't sound very family friendly, which may be one reason why there are so many empty seats.

I was a season ticket holder to the NE Revolution prior to moving to NYC in 2000. The chant was commonplace from the league's inception. You could argue it's been played out, or I could argue it's a home team tradition. Bottom line: just as the league is gaining traction it focuses on YSA? Give me break! Focus on what really will make the MLS successful, that is, increase the salary cap and get more world class players.
The only live brained sports fans in this country are soccer fans, Ralph.  What other sport in this country has a dialogue between the teams and their supporters?
Easy: those people who are very very easily offended.
Right! The violence at American gladiator "football" is much better for the kids.
Ever been to a baseball, football or hockey game? I think if you want a pure and sanitized viewing experience, you can't go wrong with the NWSL. And the standard of play is good, too.
I wonder how many parents and uncles will think twice about taking a kid to an MLS game, with this kind of behavior going on. That can't be good for the game, the league, or the fans.
We'll get out of the Gulf when the last gas guzzler has been traded in on a motor vehicle powered by something other than oil products. And not a minute before.

Yes. President Obama should begin talks that might make it possible to step-by-step lessen the sanctions in return for actions by Iran.

My many Iranian friends here in Sweden - all of them opposed to the regime, that's why they fled to Sweden - tell me the same thing. The sanctions hurt ordinary families and the lower the family is on the economic ladder the more they hurt. If sanctions do achieve positive goals from US standpoint, so be it. But gradually removing them might make hard-hit Iranians living in Iran see that the US, which bears 1953 responsibility for the creation of the regime, will benefit as will Iran if agreements can be reached.

Larry Lundgren Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

Yes indeed, let's get serious. It is now up to Obama to show that the goal is really to remove the risk of a new nuclear country, and not to punish the Iranians for supporting the Palestinians and Hezbollah.  The first is a valid goal for U.S. foreign policy, the second has nothing at all to do with U.S. interests.   It has never been clear exactly what the U.S. expects of Iran for lifting sanctions.  The Turkish foreign minister, along with Brazil negotiated a solution in 2010, but Israel and the U.S. Congress wanted sanctions.   No doubt Obama needed to support the sanctions to get re-elected.  Now he is free to enhance his legacy by getting this issue off the table.   All the problems in the Middle East require cooperation with Iran, Turkey and hopefully a democratic Egypt.

Let's get serious  .If the goal is to remove the risk of a new nuclear country, let's get with it.  Obama needs to talk at the UN.  He needs to offer a visit and visit to Iran.  Get something done so we can get out of the gulf.  They can certainly help with Iraq.

Soon, if not already, Dimon is going to set a record for fines paid by any bank in the history of USA. The fact that he continues is no credit to him but very clear evidence of the extent to which the regulatory system has been defanged.
Hm...so...should we, the US, also give up our nuclear weapons? If not why not, based on your logic?

Exactly. Why does Barack Obama and everyone else pretend that Israel does not have nuclear weapons? This would seem all the more elementary since Israel often threatens to attack Iran, perhaps hoping that in the end the US will do the attacking.

What exactly would Iran gain by attacking Israel with a nuclear weapon? Nothing. Instead, Hillary Clinton's campaign promise to obliterate Iran might be realized.

The asymmetry of everything that pretends to be a discussion on Iran is so striking to me I do not see why it is so seldom dealt with. So at least we can see it acknowledged in an NYT comment.

Larry Lundgren Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

How to get Iran to give up it's WMD program?   Get Israel to do it too.  So far, Obama has chosen to pretend Israel doesn't have one.  Iran long ago had proposed to make the middle east a nuclear free zone.   Why should they be muscled into giving up their weapons while Israel, (who people in the region consistently vote are the biggest threat to stability) keep theirs?  And for what?  Who would they use it on? At this day and age there is no justification for the use of nuclear weapons, even as a retaliatory strike.

Iran is part theocracy and part democracy. We do not understand how that works. We are part oligarchy and part democracy. They do not understand how that works. Peace between nations cannot depend on deep understanding of each other, but must rest on shared interests. When both sides have something to lose by cheating, periods of stable relations can occur. Trust, I fear, is beside the point. Who do we actually trust? France? Israel? Well, maybe Canada.

For those of us who voted for him--a majority of Americans--President Obama is indeed "...dealing from a position of strength," contrary to your assertion. He hasn't invaded other countries on the basis of false and manufactured intelligence, and he is quick to pursue negotiated settlements. He has separated to a minor degree the interests of Israel and those of the USA--unlike most of his predecessors. He prefers exchanging letters with foreign leaders instead of bombing them.

How do we know when to trust the Iranians?  "The ayatollahs still hold all the power although the spokesman has changed dramatically from Ahmadinejad to Rouhani.  Is this a real opportunity or just a change in how they stall for time?  Obama is not dealing from a position of strength so the Iranians may just be playing him. It doesn't seem hard to do, just ask Putin and Assad.

If Obama is serious, two suggestions:

1. Skip the references to Iran's "totalitarian leaders." Think what you like, but keep your objective in mind. Remarks like that make don't help.

2. Be prepared for Iran to insist on the right to enrich uranium. It always has. It always will. If you're only interested in a deal that doesn't allow that, don't waste anyone's time.
The race always narrows just before the party that was expected win does win, usually with a larger vote than expected.

As a German abroad, it is with great sadness how Germany as gone the neo-liberal way of America and all those other places in the world, where rampant greed and egoism reign supreme. Germany used to be a country build on consensus, like most of democratic post-WWII Europe. No longer. And it is also Merkel's fault for not having an alternative vision - or any vision for that matter. My vote has gone to Steinbrück, for better of for worse.
I guess everybody loves safe.
Great comment.

Its my contention that sanctions and diplomacy are the only real cards the US has to play with Iran and Syria.  I think Assad's use of chemical weapons was a last gambit before he had to knuckle under to international pressure.  First with getting rid of his chemical weapons and next recognizing that his efforts have ended up destroying Syria as it once was constituted.  These calls for arming the rebels are understandable but ultimately create more problems than they solve.  Now with Iran trying to end sanctions and participate in the world order where the US is the most powerful entity we see that President Obama may be on the verge of a major breakthrough.  The UN weapons inspectors, with Israel, the US and other powers tried moving the goal posts in their condemnation of Iran on issues which they could not prove and went counter to the fact that Iran is a signatory of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
Exactly, thanks.

In other words, you are saying the American people are just plain dumb? I can't blame the opportunists in government when dolts vote them in. The American people are to blame, they get the government they want, obviously, or things would have changed a long time ago.
You're right.  I listen to my family members talk as they vote against their interests but they love feeling superior to people of color, poor people and increasingly those "liberal snobs."

The reason Republicans can hold on to votes of poor whites as their policies make times get worse in places like Owsley County is simple;  blame someone else.  These days, as it was during the Depression, 'someone else' means Mexicans, accused of stealing jobs.  It also means 'undeserving' big city minorities.  By extension then, it means the welfare state.  Of course, that's Democrats.  No matter how Hal Rogers' policies impoverish his constituents, he can hold their loyalty with us versus them divisiveness; making them feel that white makes right.
